questions.text: In the pelvic inlet, which is the shortest anteroposterior diameter?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Obstetric conjugate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diameters of the Pelvic Inlet
  • ➤ Diameters of the Pelvic Inlet
  • ➤ Anteroposterior (AP) Diameter
  • ➤ Anteroposterior (AP) Diameter
  • ➤ True (anatomical) conjugate (11 cm): Extends from uppermost margin of symphysis pubis to the sacral promontory. Obstetric conjugate (10 cm): It is the shortest AP diameter of the pelvic inlet and hence obstetrically most important. It is measured from the middle of sacral promontory to symphysis pubis. It cannot be measured directly on clinical examination. It is calculated by subtracting 1.5 cm from diagonal conjugate. Diagonal conjugate (12.5 cm): It is measured from tip of sacral promontory to the lower margin of pubic symphysis. It is the only diameter that can be assessed clinically.
  • ➤ True (anatomical) conjugate (11 cm): Extends from uppermost margin of symphysis pubis to the sacral promontory.

questions.text: According to WHO guidelines on management of labor, which of the following is true about management of second stage of labor?

options.label: B
options.text: Episiotomy should be performed as a routine

options.label: C
options.text: A warm cloth should be applied to the perineum to prevent trauma

options.label: D
options.text: Delivery should be ideally performed in a lithotomy position

questions.correct_answer: C. A warm cloth should be applied to the perineum to prevent trauma
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. A warm cloth should be applied to the perineum to prevent trauma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ As per WHO recommendations of 2018,
  • ➤ As per WHO recommendations of 2018,
  • ➤ As per WHO guidelines on intrapartum care for a positive birth experience (2018), these are the recommendations in 2 nd stage
  • ➤ As per WHO guidelines on intrapartum care for a positive birth experience (2018), these are the recommendations in 2 nd stage
  • ➤ Definition and duration of the second stage of labor: The second stage is the period of time between full cervical dilatation and birth of the baby, during which the woman has an involuntary urge to bear down, as a result of expulsive uterine contractions. In first labors, birth is usually completed within 3 hours whereas in subsequent labors, birth is usually completed within 2 hours. Recommended Birth position (for women with or without epidural analgesia) For women without epidural analgesia, encouraging the adoption of a birth position of the individual woman’s choice, including upright positions, is recommended. Method of pushing Women in the expulsive phase of the second stage of labor should be encouraged and supported to follow their own urge to push. Method of pushing (for women with epidural analgesia) For women with epidural analgesia in the second stage of labor, delaying pushing for one to two hours after full dilatation or until the woman regains the sensory urge to bear down is recommended in the context where resources are available for longer stay in second stage and perinatal hypoxia can be adequately assessed and managed. Techniques for preventing perineal trauma. For women in the second stage of labor, techniques to reduce perineal trauma and facilitate spontaneous birth (including perineal massage, warm compresses and a “hands on” guarding of the perineum) are recommended, based on a woman’s preferences and available options. Episiotomy policy Routine or liberal use of episiotomy is not recommended for women undergoing spontaneous vaginal birth. Fundal pressure Application of manual fundal pressure to facilitate childbirth during the second stage of labor is not recommended.

questions.text: A midwife at a PHC is monitoring pregnancy and maintaining the WHO modified partograph of pregnancy progression. At how much cervical dilation should the partograph plotting be started?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. 4 cm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Partograph is a graphical representation of progress of labor, which is depicted using cervical dilatation and descent of head against the duration of labor. It is used for early detection of abnormal labor patterns for timely intervention. In a partograph the active phase of labor starts when the cervix is 4 cm dilated. In active phase, cervix should dilate at the rate of 1 cm/hr. (Alert Line) Partograph has two lines for assessment of progression of dilation Alert line: Alert line starts at 4 cm cervical dilation & ends with full dilation of the cervix (10 cm) in 7 hours (1 cm/hour dilation rate) A ction line: Action line is drawn four hours to the right of the alert line. If action line is crossed while plotting the progression, it indicates need for urgent intervention.
  • ➤ Partograph is a graphical representation of progress of labor, which is depicted using cervical dilatation and descent of head against the duration of labor.
  • ➤ It is used for early detection of abnormal labor patterns for timely intervention.
  • ➤ In a partograph the active phase of labor starts when the cervix is 4 cm dilated.
  • ➤ In active phase, cervix should dilate at the rate of 1 cm/hr. (Alert Line)
  • ➤ Partograph has two lines for assessment of progression of dilation Alert line: Alert line starts at 4 cm cervical dilation & ends with full dilation of the cervix (10 cm) in 7 hours (1 cm/hour dilation rate) A ction line: Action line is drawn four hours to the right of the alert line. If action line is crossed while plotting the progression, it indicates need for urgent intervention.
  • ➤ Alert line: Alert line starts at 4 cm cervical dilation & ends with full dilation of the cervix (10 cm) in 7 hours (1 cm/hour dilation rate) A ction line: Action line is drawn four hours to the right of the alert line. If action line is crossed while plotting the progression, it indicates need for urgent intervention.

  • ➤ Described by the WHO in 2007 Involves mainly 3 basic steps. Administering a uterotonic Controlled cord traction Uterine massage AMTSL prevents atonic PPH. In 2012, the WHO issued new guidelines for AMTSL which essentially emphasized the main 3 things but with additional information which was Oxytocin is the uterotonic of choice for AMTSL (10 IU IM/IV) Do Controlled cord traction only if a skilled birth attendant is present. Sustained uterine massage is not recommended for all women who’ve received uterotonic; instead; postpartum uterine tone assessment for early identification of uterine atony is done. Delayed cord clamping (performed after 1 to 3 minutes after birth) is recommended for all births while initiating simultaneous essential newborn care (This is not to prevent atonic PPH but was introduced along with AMTSL to ensure it is followed) In 2018, the WHO issued further guidelines on which other uterotonics can be used for AMTSL. These include: Oxytocin (10 IU IM/IV) Carbetocin (100 mcg IM/IV) Misoprostol (400 OR 600 mcg PO – to be used where Skilled birth attendant isn’t available) Ergometrine/methylergometrine (200 mcg IV EXCEPT in hypertensive women)) Oxytocin and ergometrine fixed-dose combination (5 IU/500 µg, IM) Injectable prostaglandins (carboprost or sulprostone) are not recommended for the prevention of PPH AMTSL decreases Incidence of PPH.   • ➤ Partograph
  • ➤ The WHO modified Partograph is a graphical representation of progress of labour, which is depicted using cervical dilatation and descent of head against the duration of labour. It is used for early detection of abnormal labour patterns for timely intervention. In a partograph the active phase of labour starts when the cervix is 4 cm dilated. In active phase, cervix should dilate at the rate of 1 cm/hr. Partograph has two lines for assessment of progression of dilation. Alert line: Alert line starts at 4 cm cervical dilation & ends with full dilation of the cervix (10 cm) in 7 hours (1 cm/hour dilation rate) Action line: Action line is drawn four hours to the right of the alert line. If action line is crossed while plotting the progression, it indicates need for urgent intervention.

questions.text: Following delivery of a 4kg baby to a mother with gestational diabetes, you note that there is a tear involving the perineum and external anal sphincter with intact mucosa. The grade of the tear is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Third degree

Explanation:

  • • Explanation and Other Options
  • • First degree: Injury to perineal skin Second degree: Injury to perineum involving perineal body (muscles) but not involving the anal sphincter. Third degree: Injury to perineum, involving the anal sphincter complex (both the external and internal). 3a: if half thickness external anal sphincter involved. 3b: if full thickness external anal sphincter involved. 3c: if internal anal sphincter involved. Fourth degree: Injury to perineum involving the anal sphincter complex (external anal sphincter and internal anal sphincter) and anal epithelium.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman in labor presents with an occiput posterior position. What is a potential maternal complaint commonly associated with it?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Back pain

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This is the most common complaint associated with the occiput posterior position. The back of the baby's head pressing against the mother's sacrum can cause intense lower back pain, often referred to as "back labor." This pain can persist throughout labor and is often exacerbated during contractions.
  • • Other Options :
  • • Other Options
  • • Option B: While abdominal pain is common during labor regardless of the fetal position, the OP position does not specifically cause more severe abdominal pain than other positions. However, labor might be longer and more painful overall due to the suboptimal alignment of the baby's head with the maternal pelvis. Option C: Frequent urination is a common symptom of occipitoposterior Option D: Shoulder pain or discomfort during pregnancy might be related to changes in posture, stress on the spine, or could be referred pain from gallbladder issues, which can be more common in pregnancy, but it's not a symptom commonly linked to fetal position in labor.
  • • Option B: While abdominal pain is common during labor regardless of the fetal position, the OP position does not specifically cause more severe abdominal pain than other positions. However, labor might be longer and more painful overall due to the suboptimal alignment of the baby's head with the maternal pelvis.

questions.text: A 32yr G2P1 is referred at her 36 weeks from the primary health center with prolonged labor. On examination, the patient is dehydrated. Abdominal examination reveals a 32 weeks uterus which is tonically contracted. The presentation is unclear. Fetal heart rate is absent. On local examination, the hand is seen outside the introitus. What is the next best step?

options.label: C
options.text: Reposit the hand back and external version

options.label: D
options.text: Reposit the hand back and internal version

questions.explanation: Ans. A. Cesarean section

questions.text: A 25y woman presents at 37 weeks in early labor. After a few hours, the patient complains of leaking per vaginum. The CTG shows a prolonged deceleration and on vaginal examination, the cord is felt in the vagina. The cervix is 8cm dilated. What is the next best step?
questions.correct_answer: B. Lift the presenting part up
questions.explanation: Ans. B. Lift the presenting part up

questions.text: Match the maneuver used in shoulder dystocia with the description:
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Shoulder Dystocia Maneuvers
  • ➤ Shoulder Dystocia Maneuvers
  • ➤ McRoberts maneuver: - Hyperflexion of mother’s legs onto the abdomen during child birth This widens the pelvis, and flattens the lumbar spine. Suprapubic pressure: directional (45° downward) pressure to the maternal abdomen just above the pubic symphysis. This pressure should be applied to the posterior aspect of the anterior shoulder, pushing toward the opposite side from where the attendant is positioned. Suprapubic pressure is often used concomitantly with the McRoberts maneuver. Rubin II or posterior pressure on the anterior shoulder, which would bring the fetus in an oblique position with head somewhat towards the vagina Woods’ screw maneuver which leads to turning the anterior shoulder to the posterior and vice versa (somewhat the opposite of Rubin II maneuver) Gaskin maneuver involves moving the mother to an all fours position with the back arched, widening the pelvic outlet. Zaninelli’s maneuver, which involves pushing the fetal head back in with performing a cesarean section. or internal cephalic replacement followed by Cesarean section. Intentional fetal clavicular fracture, which reduces the diameter of the shoulder girdle that requires to pass through the birth canal. Maternal symphysiotomy, which makes the opening of the birth canal laxer by breaking the connective tissue between the two pubes bones facilitating the passage of the shoulders. Abdominal rescue, described by O’Shaughnessy. where a hysterotomy facilitates vaginal delivery of the impacted shoulder

questions.text: A 24 - year primi presents in active labor at 40 weeks’ gestation. Delivery of the fetal head occurs, but the fetal shoulders do not deliver despite several attempts. To resolve it, McRoberts maneuver was done. Which of the following describes this maneuver?

options.label: A
options.text: Anterior rotation of the symphysis pubis

options.label: D
options.text: Displaces the fetal shoulder axis from anterior posterior (AP) to oblique

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman who is otherwise healthy, has an uneventful vaginal delivery of a full-term infant. One day postpartum, she complains of visual changes and a severe headache. Two hours after this, she is found unresponsive and profoundly hypotensive. She is intubated and put on mechanical ventilation. Her BP is 68/28 mmHg. Heart rate is 140 bp. O2 saturation is 95% on FiO2 of 0.40. Physical exam is unremarkable. Lab tests are notable for glucose of 48 mg/ dl with a normal hematocrit and TLC. Which of the following will reverse her hypotension?

options.label: D
options.text: Transfusion of packed red blood cells

questions.explanation: Ans. B. Hydrocortisone

questions.text: A 34y G2 who was induced for severe preeclampsia at 34 weeks has just delivered. Which is the uterotonic drug of choice in the 3 rd stage of labor?
questions.explanation: Ans. C. Inj Oxytocin 10 IU IV

questions.text: A 35y asthmatic was induced for FGR at 37 weeks. She is now in the 3 rd stage of labor having delivered a 2 kg female baby. Following delivery of the placenta, she starts bleeding profusely. The uterus is atonic. Which uterotone will NOT be given?
questions.explanation: Ans. B. Carboprost.

questions.text: A female presents with significant blood loss due to postpartum hemorrhage. What would be the shock index?
questions.explanation: Ans. C.  0.9 to 1.1

questions.text: A female sustained massive PPH during delivery and presented with failure of lactation and amenorrhea 1 year later. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Ans. C. Sheehan syndrome

questions.text: In 2017, the WHO recommended the use of tranexamic acid (TXA) for the treatment of PPH. What is the recommended dose?

options.label: A
options.text: TXA should be administered at a dose of 1 g in 10 mL IV given as soon as PPH is identified and within 3 hours of birth. A second dose may be repeated after 15 minutes if required.

options.label: B
options.text: TXA should be administered at a dose of 1 g in 10 mL IV given as soon as PPH is identified and within 3 hours of birth. A second dose may be repeated after 30 minutes if required.

options.label: C
options.text: TXA should be administered at a dose of 0.5 g in 10 mL IV given as soon as PPH is identified and within 3 hours of birth. A second dose may be repeated after 30 minutes if required

options.label: D
options.text: TXA should be administered at a dose of 0.5 g in 10 mL IV given as soon as PPH is identified and within 3 hours of birth. A second dose may be repeated after 15 minutes if required

questions.correct_answer: B. TXA should be administered at a dose of 1 g in 10 mL IV given as soon as PPH is identified and within 3 hours of birth. A second dose may be repeated after 30 minutes if required.
questions.explanation: Ans. B.

questions.text: While assisting a cesarean section for placenta previa, the patient starts bleeding. The gynecologist applies the following suture on the uterus and asks the name of it. What is this suture called?
questions.explanation: Ans. B. B Lynch suture
